    Line 45: Line 45:      
==Religious perspectives==
 
==Religious perspectives==
−
{{see|Sophia (wisdom)}}
+
{{See|Sophia (wisdom)}}
 
Some religions have specific teachings relating to wisdom.
 
Some religions have specific teachings relating to wisdom.
     
===Abrahamic religions (Old Testament)===
 
===Abrahamic religions (Old Testament)===
    −
In the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Bible]] and [[Judaism|Jewish]] scripture, wisdom is represented by the sense of justice of the lawful and wise king [[Solomon]], who asks God for wisdom in [[1 Kings]] 3. Much of the [[Book of Proverbs|Book of Proverbs]], a book of wise sayings, is attributed to Solomon. In Proverbs 1:7 and 9:10, the [[Fear_of_the_lord|fear of the Lord]] is called the beginning or foundation of wisdom while Proverbs 8:13 declares "To fear the Lord is to hate evil". In Proverbs 1:20, there is also reference to wisdom personified in female form, "Wisdom calls aloud in the street, she raises her voice in the public squares."
+
In the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Bible]] and [[Judaism|Jewish]] scripture, wisdom is represented by the sense of justice of the lawful and wise king [[Solomon]], who asks God for wisdom in [[1 Kings]] 3. Much of the [[Book of Proverbs]], a book of wise sayings, is attributed to Solomon. In Proverbs 1:7 and 9:10, the [[Fear of the lord|fear of the Lord]] is called the beginning or foundation of wisdom while Proverbs 8:13 declares "To fear the Lord is to hate evil". In Proverbs 1:20, there is also reference to wisdom personified in female form, "Wisdom calls aloud in the street, she raises her voice in the public squares."
     
===Abrahamic religions (New Testament)===
 
===Abrahamic religions (New Testament)===
    −
Furthermore, there is an oppositional element in Christian thought between [[secular]] wisdom and Godly wisdom. The [[apostle Paul]] states that worldly wisdom thinks the claims of [[Christ]] to be foolishness. However, to those who are being saved Christ represents the wisdom of God. ([[1 Corinthians]] 1:17-31) Also, Wisdom is one of the [[Seven gifts of the Holy Spirit|seven gifts of the Holy Spirit]] according to Anglican, Catholic, and Lutheran belief. 1 Corinthians 12:8-10 gives an alternate list of nine virtues, among which wisdom is one.
+
Furthermore, there is an oppositional element in Christian thought between [[secular]] wisdom and Godly wisdom. The [[apostle Paul]] states that worldly wisdom thinks the claims of [[Christ]] to be foolishness. However, to those who are being saved Christ represents the wisdom of God. ([[1 Corinthians]] 1:17-31) Also, Wisdom is one of the [[seven gifts of the Holy Spirit]] according to Anglican, Catholic, and Lutheran belief. 1 Corinthians 12:8-10 gives an alternate list of nine virtues, among which wisdom is one.
    −
===Abrahamic religions ([[Qur'an]])===
+
===Abrahamic religions (Qur'an)===
    −
In [[Islam]], according to the [[Qur'an]], all of the prophets of the Old Testament, Jesus, as well as the Prophet [[Muhammad]] were chosen by Allah, mostly in times of political or moral crisis, to represent his wisdom. The Prophet [[Muhammad]] said that: "Fearing [[Allah]] in your actions and intentions, and knowing that Almighty [[Allah]] is watching you wherever and whenever you are is the head/peak of wisdom"{{Fact|date=March 2007}}. In addition, Islam also mentions that a wise man with the name of [[Luqman (person)|''Luqman'']] once told his son to: "Sit with the learned men and keep close to them. [[Allah]] gives life to the hearts with the light of wisdom as Allah gives life to the dead earth with the abundant rain of the sky"[http://www.usc.edu/dept/MSA/fundamentals/hadithsunnah/muwatta/059.mmt.html#059.59.1.1].
+
In [[Islam]], according to the [[Qur'an]], all of the prophets of the Old Testament, Jesus, as well as the Prophet [[Muhammad]] were chosen by Allah, mostly in times of political or moral crisis, to represent his wisdom. The Prophet [[Muhammad]] said that: "Fearing [[Allah]] in your actions and intentions, and knowing that Almighty [[Allah]] is watching you wherever and whenever you are is the head/peak of wisdom"{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}}. In addition, Islam also mentions that a wise man with the name of [[Luqman (person)|''Luqman'']] once told his son to: "Sit with the learned men and keep close to them. [[Allah]] gives life to the hearts with the light of wisdom as Allah gives life to the dead earth with the abundant rain of the sky"[http://www.usc.edu/dept/MSA/fundamentals/hadithsunnah/muwatta/059.mmt.html#059.59.1.1].
     
===Eastern religions and philosophy===
 
===Eastern religions and philosophy===
Line 81: Line 81:  
{{Citations missing|date=September 2007}}
 
{{Citations missing|date=September 2007}}
 
[[Image:Wisdom-Reid-Highsmith.jpeg|thumb|left|[[Robert Reid (painter)|Robert Reid]], ''Wisdom'' (1896). [[Thomas Jefferson Building]], Washington, D.C.]]
 
[[Image:Wisdom-Reid-Highsmith.jpeg|thumb|left|[[Robert Reid (painter)|Robert Reid]], ''Wisdom'' (1896). [[Thomas Jefferson Building]], Washington, D.C.]]
−
A standard [[philosophy|philosophical]] definition says that wisdom consists of making the best use of available [[propositional knowledge|knowledge]]. As with any decision, a wise decision may be made with incomplete [[information]]{{Fact|date=March 2007}}. The technical philosophical term for the opposite of wisdom is ''folly''.{{Fact|date=March 2007}}
+
A standard [[philosophy|philosophical]] definition says that wisdom consists of making the best use of available [[propositional knowledge|knowledge]]. As with any decision, a wise decision may be made with incomplete [[information]]{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}}. The technical philosophical term for the opposite of wisdom is ''folly''.{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}}
     
In his ''[[Metaphysics (Aristotle)|Metaphysics]]'', [[Aristotle]] defines wisdom as knowledge of causes: ''why'' things exist in a particular fashion.
 
In his ''[[Metaphysics (Aristotle)|Metaphysics]]'', [[Aristotle]] defines wisdom as knowledge of causes: ''why'' things exist in a particular fashion.
    −
In addition to experience there are a variety of other avenues to gaining wisdom. For example, [[Freethought|Freethinkers]] and others believe that wisdom may come from pure [[reason]] and perhaps experience, while others believe that it comes from [[intuition (knowledge)|intuition]] or [[spirituality]].{{Fact|date=March 2007}}
+
In addition to experience there are a variety of other avenues to gaining wisdom. For example, [[Freethought|Freethinkers]] and others believe that wisdom may come from pure [[reason]] and perhaps experience, while others believe that it comes from [[intuition (knowledge)|intuition]] or [[spirituality]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}}
     
Beginning with the ancient Greeks, European culture associates wisdom with [[virtue]]. [[Metis (mythology)|Metis]] and [[Athene]] are associated with wisdom from earliest times. For example, many philosophers talk about the virtue of wisdom in relation to courage and moderation, and in the [[Roman Catholic]] church, wisdom ([[Prudence]]) stands with [[justice]], [[fortitude]] and [[moderation]] as one of the four [[cardinal virtues]]. [[Plato]]'s dialogues mention the virtue of wisdom, as knowledge about the Good and the [[courage]] to act accordingly. The [[Good]] would be about the right relations between all that exists. The Good, as a Platonic [[Form]], would involve the perfect ideas of good government, love, friendship, community, and a right relation to the Divine. Perhaps the search or love of wisdom is more important than any proven claim. Socrates only claimed to know that he did not know, but this he was very certain of, and he showed the many contradictions in the claims of his fellow citizens.<ref>Plato. "Apology." ''The Republic and other Works'' New York: Anchor, 1989. p. 450. ISBN 0-385-09497-3</ref>
 
Beginning with the ancient Greeks, European culture associates wisdom with [[virtue]]. [[Metis (mythology)|Metis]] and [[Athene]] are associated with wisdom from earliest times. For example, many philosophers talk about the virtue of wisdom in relation to courage and moderation, and in the [[Roman Catholic]] church, wisdom ([[Prudence]]) stands with [[justice]], [[fortitude]] and [[moderation]] as one of the four [[cardinal virtues]]. [[Plato]]'s dialogues mention the virtue of wisdom, as knowledge about the Good and the [[courage]] to act accordingly. The [[Good]] would be about the right relations between all that exists. The Good, as a Platonic [[Form]], would involve the perfect ideas of good government, love, friendship, community, and a right relation to the Divine. Perhaps the search or love of wisdom is more important than any proven claim. Socrates only claimed to know that he did not know, but this he was very certain of, and he showed the many contradictions in the claims of his fellow citizens.<ref>Plato. "Apology." ''The Republic and other Works'' New York: Anchor, 1989. p. 450. ISBN 0-385-09497-3</ref>
Line 91: Line 91:  
In the [[Inuit]] tradition, developing wisdom was the aim of teaching. An Inuit Elder said that a person became wise when they could see what needed to be done and do it successfully without being told what to do.<ref>Johnny Morgan, Inuit Elder: Silatunirmut, 1991</ref>
 
In the [[Inuit]] tradition, developing wisdom was the aim of teaching. An Inuit Elder said that a person became wise when they could see what needed to be done and do it successfully without being told what to do.<ref>Johnny Morgan, Inuit Elder: Silatunirmut, 1991</ref>
    −
[[Holistic|Holists]] believe that wise people sense, work with and align themselves and others to [[life]]. In this view, wise people help others appreciate the fundamental [[interconnectedness]] of life{{Fact|date=May 2007}}.
+
[[Holistic|Holists]] believe that wise people sense, work with and align themselves and others to [[life]]. In this view, wise people help others appreciate the fundamental [[interconnectedness]] of life{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}}.
     
[[Nicholas Maxwell]], a modern philosopher, argued that the basic aim of academic inquiry ought to be to seek and promote wisdom — wisdom being construed to be the capacity to realize what is of value in life for oneself and others, wisdom thus including knowledge and technological know-how, but much else besides.<ref name = "Maxwell">[http://www.nick-maxwell.demon.co.uk MAXWELL, Nicholas].</ref>
 
[[Nicholas Maxwell]], a modern philosopher, argued that the basic aim of academic inquiry ought to be to seek and promote wisdom — wisdom being construed to be the capacity to realize what is of value in life for oneself and others, wisdom thus including knowledge and technological know-how, but much else besides.<ref name = "Maxwell">[http://www.nick-maxwell.demon.co.uk MAXWELL, Nicholas].</ref>
    −
[[Anil K. Rajvanshi]] another modern philosopher who has written extensively on the issues of spirituality and technology argues that wisdom is an outcome of the expansion of our horizons. An evolved brain becomes acutely aware of its surroundings and with its powerful processor is able to expand its horizons to encompass our world, solar system and universe. This expansion of consciousness gives us a tremendous sense of peace, tranquility and perspective on our life which in totality is called wisdom.<ref>Art and Science of Happiness[http://www.nariphaltan.org/life.htm]</ref>{{Or}}{{Clarifyme}}
+
[[Anil K. Rajvanshi]] another modern philosopher who has written extensively on the issues of spirituality and technology argues that wisdom is an outcome of the expansion of our horizons. An evolved brain becomes acutely aware of its surroundings and with its powerful processor is able to expand its horizons to encompass our world, solar system and universe. This expansion of consciousness gives us a tremendous sense of peace, tranquility and perspective on our life which in totality is called wisdom.<ref>[http://www.nariphaltan.org/life.htm Art and Science of Happiness]</ref>{{Or|date=July 2009}}{{Clarify|date=July 2009}}
